title: Governments back upgrade for NSW-Qld power line
text:
TransGrid chief executive Paul Italiano said federal and NSW government support was essential to the early delivery of the transmission project.

"TransGrid is building the interconnector to ensure a reliable supply of electricity to customers over the summers ahead and as older, coal-fired generators shut down," he said.

TransGrid CEO Paul Italiano praised the government support for early works. Daniel Munoz

The government underwriting for early works for QNI comes ahead of the final regulatory determination of the project by the Australian Energy Regulator.

Prime Minister Scott Morrison and NSW Premier Gladys Berejiklian said the $51 million each government was offering would ensure the security of electricity in NSW.

“This is about putting downward pressure on wholesale prices to make sure businesses and households have access to reliable and affordable power," Mr Morrison said.

“Industry needs certainty. They need to know their electricity won’t cut out, and their power bill won’t suddenly double."

“That’s why we are underwriting this interconnector. It’s a practical step to make sure it happens, and it happens quickly."

Advertisement

Transgrid was privatised by the NSW government in 2015.

The existing main interconnector between NSW and Queensland, known as the QNI, is close to full capacity and is mostly one-way traffic heading south, with up to 1000 megawatts being shifted to NSW some days to help with high demand.

Queensland has a comparatively younger fleet of coal-fired power stations, which can help with any potential shortfall in NSW, as well as existing gas fields.

TransGrid had said an expanded interconnector between NSW and Queensland would be cheaper than building new generation to replace AGL Energy's Liddell coal-fired power plant.

NSW Premier Gladys Berejiklian said the NSW government was committed to providing reliable and affordable electricity to the people of NSW.

“The QNI upgrade will ease cost of living pressures for people across NSW, providing reliable and affordable power to households and businesses,” Ms Berejiklian said.

The governments said their liability would only be for any early work costs not approved by the Australian Energy Regulator as part of its regulatory assessment.

The NSW-Queensland transmission interconnector was declared a high-priority project under the Australian Energy Market Operator’s Integrated System Plan.

Advertisement

The regulator also recommended an upgrade to the VNI between Victoria and NSW.

The government opted not to underwrite VNI.

"This was not required as the regulatory assessment process found a lower cost engineering option for VNI which will deliver upgrades for an additional 170 MW of capacity from the existing Snowy Mountain hydroelectric scheme by September 2021," the government said.

A government source said the announced QNI support will allow TransGrid to deploy capital to invest in the NSW-Victoria interconnector, amid concerns the southern state is facing energy reliability risks during peak demand periods in hot weather.
description: The move aims to shore up energy security and reliability as concerns mount about potential power shortages this summer.
